docs.abstract: What's Doing In column describes upcoming events, sights, lodging and restaurants in Edinburgh, Scotland; photos; map; chart (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: August may be the best month of all to visit Edinburgh, the most regal of Scottish cities. Not only are the northern days still delightfully long but it is also the month for the Edinburgh International Festival, a world-renowned feast of music, dance and theater. Most of Edinburgh is given over to the festival, as international companies, including the New York City Ballet, Czech Philharmonic Orchestra and Royal Dramatic Theater in Stockholm, take over theaters and concert halls, leaving the visitor thoroughly spoiled for choice. It has been a year since Scotland embarked on a bold democratic experiment, swearing in its first England-free Parliament in almost 300 years and getting to run its own affairs when it comes to things like education and health. The new legislators have yet to move into their custom-made building at Holyrood, but construction can be observed in the Old City, on Edinburgh's south side. When Parliament is in session, the legislators themselves can be seen building Scotland's new political order in their temporary headquarters, near the George IV Bridge.

headline.main: Juror Says a 'Sense of Mission' Led to Huge Tobacco Damages

docs.abstract: Leighton Finegan, forman of six-member jury in Miami that punished tobacco industry with $144.8 billion punitive damages judgment, largest damage award in history, says it was tobacco industry's lies that led to jury's verdict, int; asserts that for 50 years, tobacco companies betlittled or denied causation of health effects of smoking and addiction, and 'had the gall to challenge public health authorities'; says that he went into the trial believing that a person smoked cigarettes as a choice, but found among his fellow jurors a reasoned and unanimous conviction to punish tobacco industry because companies knew they were selling a defective product, and then denied that it was defective; photo (M)

byline.original: By RICK BRAGG with SARAH KERSHAW

docs.lead_paragraph: It was the lies, the jury's foreman said today. ''For a period of 50 years, these tobacco companies denied the dangers of their product,'' said Leighton A. Finegan, the foreman of a six-member jury here that punished the tobacco industry with a $144.8 billion punitive damage judgment, the largest damage award in history.
